facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 22, 1955, of the Nagpur High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 2 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 22, 1955, of the Nagpur High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 2 of 1955.

facts.text: Single Judge of Nagpur High Court passed order dated December 13, 1954, refusing to issue writ of certiorari.

anchor.surface_text: passed by the Letters Patent Bench of the Nagpur High Court reversing those of a single Judge of that Court, dated December 13, 1954, refusing to issue a writ in the nature of a certiorari.

facts.text: Suwarna Transport Company Limited held seven permits for running buses on the Buldana-Malkapur route as the sole operator.

anchor.surface_text: The Suwarna Transport Company Limited, which will be referred to as the first respondent in the course of this judgment, held seven permits for running buses on the Buldana-Malkapur route, as the sole operator on that route.

facts.text: Suwarna Transport Company Limited applied for another permit on Buldana-Malkapur route.

anchor.surface_text: It applied for another permit for the same route.

facts.text: New Prakash Transport Co. Ltd. and Navjivan Transport Service applied for permit on Buldana-Malkapur route.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, The New Prakash Transport Co. Ltd., as also another party, called the Navjivan Transport Service applied for a similar permit on that route.

facts.text: On May 26, 1953, Regional Transport Authority of Amraoti heard all three applicants and passed resolution that no one service should have monopoly on Buldana-Malkapur route.

anchor.surface_text: On May 26, 1953, all the three applicants aforesaid were heard by the Regional Transport Authority of Amraoti, which is the third respondent in this Court, in connection with the permit applied for. Consideration of the several applications was postponed, but a resolution was passed to the effect that No one service should have monopoly on Buldana-Malkapur route.

facts.text: On March 30, 1954, Regional Transport Authority granted permit to first respondent (Suwarna) and rejected appellant's application on ground of police report against it.

anchor.surface_text: On March 30, 1954, another meeting of the Regional Transport Authority took place and the first respondent was granted the permit. The appellants application was rejected on the ground that the police report was against it.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Appellate Authority constituted under R. 73 of Motor Vehicles Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant preferred an appeal to the Appellate Authority constituted under R. 73 of the Motor -Vehicles Act , Madhya Pradesh, Nagpur, which is the second respondent to this appeal.

facts.text: Appellant challenged police report and obtained further report from District Superintendent of Police dated May 13, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged the correctness of the police report against it and applied to the District Superintendent of Police personally to verify the facts stated in the first report on the basis of which the appellants application for permit had been rejected, as aforesaid. The police made a further report... report dated May 13, 1954

facts.text: Further police report was read out to parties by Chairman of Appellate Authority at hearing, no objection raised.

anchor.surface_text: That further report by the police was read out to the parties by the Chairman of the Appellate Authority at the time of the hearing of the appeal. At the hearing no objection appears to have been raised by any of the parties

facts.text: On July 29, 1954, Appellate Authority set aside RTA order, allowed appeal, ordered permit to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated July 29, 1954, the second respondent set aside the order of the third respondent, allowed the appeal and ordered the permit to be issued to the appellant.

facts.text: First respondent filed writ petition in Nagpur High Court under Art. 226 for certiorari on grounds of error apparent and violation of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent moved the High Court at Nagpur for a writ of certiorari under Art. 226 of the Constitution, substantially on two grounds, namely, 1 that the order passed by the second respondent was vitiated by an error apparent on the face of the record, and 2 that it contravened the principles of natural justice.

facts.text: Single Judge Mr. Justice V. R. Sen discharged rule on December 13, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The petition under Arts. 226 and 227 made, as aforesaid, by the first respondent was heard by a single Judge Mr. Justice V. R. Sen who by his orders dated December 13, 1954, discharged the rule with costs.

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal heard by Chief Justice Hidayatulla and Mr. Justice S. P. Kotwal, reversed single judge, quashed Appellate Authority order, directed rehearing.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was heard by a Division Bench consisting of Chief Justice Hidayatulla and Mr. Justice S. P. Kotwal... In the result it granted a writ quashing the order of the Appellate Authority and directing it to rehear the appeal

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Having been unsuccessful there, the appellant came up to this Court and obtained special leave to appeal.

facts.text: First police report dated March 27, 1954, full of mistakes, rejected appellant's application.

anchor.surface_text: admitted that the third respondent had rejected its application on the basis of the police report dated March 27, 1954, which was full of mistakes and falsehoods

facts.text: Appellant admitted that fresh police report absolved it from allegations in first report.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant while showing cause, admitted that the third respondent had rejected its application on the basis of the police report dated March 27, 1954, which was full of mistakes and falsehoods, that it moved the District Superintendent of Police personally to verify the contents of the said report and that the fresh report submitted by the police after due verification had absolved the appellant from the allegations of misconduct contained in the first report.

facts.text: Second respondent corroborated that first police report modified by report dated May 13, 1954, based on misunderstanding.

anchor.surface_text: The second respondent also showed cause and corroborated the appellants statement that the first police report had been subsequently modified by the District Superintendent of Police by the report dated May 13, 1954, which showed that the previous report was based on some misunderstanding.

facts.text: Single Judge found no substance in contentions of violation of natural justice or error on face of record.

anchor.surface_text: the learned Judge after referring in detail to the orders of the authorities under the Motor Vehicles Act, that is to say, the second and third respondents, observed that there was no substance in the contention that the procedure adopted by the Appellate Authority was opposed to the principles of natural justice

facts.text: Letters Patent Bench found no error apparent on face but held failure of natural justice due to no proper chance to study second police report.

anchor.surface_text: The Letters Patent Bench seemed to be inclined to negative the plea that there was a mistake apparent on the face of the record... On the second ground it differed from the learned single Judge and came to the conclusion that the Appellate Authority erred in rushing through without giving a proper and effective chance to the appellant to state its case.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no failure of natural justice as report was read out, no objection or adjournment requested.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the fact that the Appellate Authority had read out the contents of the police report was enough compliance with the rules of natural justice.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court judgment and restored single Judge's view.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons aforesaid, in our opinion, the judgment under appeal is erroneous and must be set aside and we are further of the opinion that the judgment of the learned single Judge of that Court had taken the more correct view of the legal position.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 22, 1955, of the Nagpur High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 2 of 1955.

The first respondent moved the High Court at Nagpur for a writ of certiorari under Art. 226 of the Constitution, substantially on two grounds, namely,  1  that the order passed by the second respondent was vitiated by an error apparent on the face of the record, and  2  that it contravened the principles of natural justice.

arguments.claim: No error apparent on face of record; language may refer to first report but matters align with second report.

anchor.surface_text: Though the High Court on appeal did not base its decision on the other question, namely, whether there was any error apparent on the face of the record, it was sought to be argued that there was an error in the order of the second respondent in so far as it made reference to only the first report and read into it the matter contained in the subsequent report.

arguments.claim: No failure of natural justice; Appellate Authority functioned quasi-judicially per statute and rules; reading out report complies; no objection or adjournment requested; police report is informational, not evidence requiring copy.

anchor.surface_text: the Appellate Authority had to function in a quasi-judicial capacity in accordance with the rules made under the Motor Vehicles Act... In our opinion, therefore, the fact that the Appellate Authority had read out the contents of the police report was enough compliance with the rules of natural justice.

arguments.claim: Statutory scheme (ss.47,48,64, r.73) requires hearing interested persons but no court-like trial, oath, or evidence recording; notice to interested persons including opponents.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection reference was made to the provisions of ss. 47, 48 and 64 of the Motor Vehicles Act read along with the relevant rules framed under s. 68 of the Act... r. 73 framed... shall hear such persons as may appear and, after such further enquiry, if any, as it may deem necessary...

arguments.claim: Precedents (Spackman, Rice, Arlidge, etc.) show natural justice varies by statute; quasi-judicial bodies follow statutory procedure, not court rules; fair opportunity but no adjournment unless requested.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore to examine the precedents discussed in detail in the judgment under appeal... Board of Education v. Rice... Local Government Board v. Arlidge...

arguments.claim: High Court erred in assuming tribunal must provide copy and adjourn suo motu; no grievance raised at hearing; report not adverse to first respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court has made a number of assumptions... The tribunal in question was not administering justice as a court of law... a tribunal even acting judicially is not obliged to grant an adjournment suo motu without any application...

holdings.text: there is no substance in the second ground sought to be resuscitated [...] no such mistake has been shown to have vitiated the orders impugned before the High Court

anchor.surface_text: Though the High Court on appeal did not base its decision on the other question, namely, whether there was any error apparent on the face of the record, it was sought to be argued that there was an error in the order of the second respondent in so far as it made reference to only the first report and read into it the matter contained in the subsequent report.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Error apparent requires self-evident assumption of facts not on record; Appellate Authority's ambiguous language considered both reports, no vitiation shown

holdings.text: Error apparent on the face of the record in the context of this case must mean an assumption of facts which are not borne out by the record

anchor.surface_text: Error apparent on the face of the record in the context of this case must mean an assumption of facts which are not borne out by the record. We are not concerned with other grounds which may in the context of each particular case support a contention of error apparent on the face of the record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defines error apparent narrowly for certiorari; applied to police reports on record

holdings.text: the fact that the Appellate Authority had read out the contents of the police report was enough compliance with the rules of natural justice

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the fact that the Appellate Authority had read out the contents of the police report was enough compliance with the rules of natural justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Report read aloud at hearing, no objection or request for copy/adjourn; suffices given statutory scheme and no prejudice

holdings.text: a tribunal even acting judicially is not obliged to grant an adjournment suo motu without any application on behalf of any of the parties interested

anchor.surface_text: But a tribunal even acting judicially is not obliged to grant an adjournment suo motu without any application on behalf of any of the parties interested. We do not find that any of the parties made at that time any grievance about the procedure adopted by the Appellate Authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No duty to adjourn without request; parties waived by silence; applies even to judicially acting tribunals

holdings.text: the police report submitted [...] is not intended to be anything more than an expression of opinion [...] in the nature of information supplied by the police in order to assist the authority

anchor.surface_text: But the police report submitted to the Regional Transport Authority or to the Appellate Authority [...] is not intended to be anything more than an expression of opinion by an authority interested in the maintenance of law and order [...] Such a report is meant more for the use of the authority in making or refusing a grant than for the use of the several applicants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Police report informational aid to authority, not formal evidence requiring disclosure like court documents

holdings.text: there is no warrant for [proposition that natural justice requirements cannot be waived by parties]

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no warrant for such a proposition. Even in a court of law a party is not entitled to raise the question at the appellate stage that he should have been granted an adjournment which he did not pray for in the court of first instance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parties cannot raise procedural grievance post-decision if not raised timely; no waiver exception for natural justice

holdings.text: the judgment under appeal is erroneous and must be set aside and [...] the judgment of the learned single Judge of that Court had taken the more correct view of the legal position

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons aforesaid, in our opinion, the judgment under appeal is erroneous and must be set aside and we are further of the opinion that the judgment of the learned single Judge of that Court had taken the more correct view of the legal position.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in finding natural justice violation; single judge correctly found compliance and no error

precedents.citation: Spackman Plumstead Board of Works 1 ... 1 1885 10 A.C. 229, 240.

anchor.surface_text: the case of Spackman Plumstead Board of Works 1 . In that case the question arose on a prosecution for infringement of an Act of Parliament making provision for fixing the general line of buildings in a road. The certificate of the superintending architect as to the general line of buildings came in for discussion as to whether the architect, before deciding as to how the general line has to be fixed, had to hear the parties companyserned. In that companysention the Earl of Selborne, L.C., made the following observations - No doubt, in the absence of special provisions as to how the person who is to decide is to proceed, the law will imply numbermore than that the substantial requirements of justice shall number be violated.

precedents.case_name: Spackman v. Plumstead Board of Works
precedents.cited_proposition: Substantial requirements of natural justice require giving parties opportunity to be heard, notice, and acting honestly and impartially, without formal procedure unless specified.
precedents.cited_holding: He must give the parties an opportunity of being heard before him and stating their case and their view. He must give notice when he will proceed with the matter, and he must act honestly and impartially.

anchor.surface_text: Another leading case on the subject is the decision of the House of Lords in the well-known case of Board of Education Rice 1 . Their Lordships in that case had to discuss the duty of the Board of Education under s. 7 of the Education Act, 1902. Lord Loreburn, L.C., in the course of his speech referred to the provisions of the Act and made the following observations as to the duty to decide certain questions relating to nonprovided schools- Comparatively recent statutes have extended, if they have not originated, the practice of imposing upon departments, or officers of State the duty of deciding or determining questions of various kinds.

precedents.cited_proposition: Administrative bodies must act in good faith, fairly listen to both sides, obtain information as they think best, and give fair opportunity to correct prejudicial statements, but not conduct a trial.
precedents.cited_holding: They can obtain information in any way they think best, always giving a fair opportunity to those who are parties in the controversy for correcting or contradicting any relevant statement prejudicial to their view.

precedents.citation: Rex v. Local Government Board, Ex parte Arlidge 1 ... 1 1913 1 K.B, 463.

anchor.surface_text: How far judicial opinion may vary as to the content of the rule of natural justice is amply illustrated by the case of Rex v. Local Government Board, Ex parte Arlidge 1 , at different stages. The rule nisi for a certiorari was first heard by Ridley, Lord Coleridge and Bankes, JJ. The case related to the powers of the, Local Government Board under the Housing, Town Planning, etc. Act, 1909  9 Edw. 7, c. 44  refusing to terminate its orders closing a dwelling- house as unfit for habitation and the procedure for hearing an appeal against such an order.

precedents.case_name: Rex v. Local Government Board, Ex parte Arlidge
precedents.cited_proposition: Local Government Board not bound to hear appellant after inspector's report if procedure per rules followed.

precedents.citation: Rex v. Local Government Board, Ex parte A rlidge 2 ... 2 1914 1 K. B. 16o

anchor.surface_text: The matter was taken in appeal in Rex v. Local Government Board, Ex parte A rlidge 2 , and the Court of Appeal by a majority  Vaughan Williams and Buckley, L.JJ., Hamilton, L.J. dissenting  allowed the appeal holding that it was contrary to the principles of natural justice that the Board should have dismissed the appeal without disclosing to the appellant the contents of their inspectors report and without giving the appellant an opportunity of being heard in support of the appeal.

precedents.case_name: Rex v. Local Government Board, Ex parte Arlidge
precedents.cited_proposition: Dismissal of appeal without disclosing inspector's report and giving opportunity to be heard violates natural justice.

precedents.citation: Local Government Board v. Arlidge 1 ... 1 1915 A.C. 120, 132.

anchor.surface_text: Against the judgment of the majority of the Court quashing the determination of the appeal by the Board there was an appeal to the House of Lords. The House of Lords unanimously adopted the opinion of Hamilton, L.J.  later Lord Sumner , allowed the appeal and set aside the majority decision. Vide Local Government Board v. Arlidge 1 . In the course of his speech Viscount Haldane, L.C., made the following observations- My Lords, when the duty of deciding an appeal is imposed, those whose duty it is to decide it must act judicially.

precedents.cited_proposition: Quasi-judicial tribunals must act judicially without bias, give opportunity to present case, but procedure need not be the same as courts; depends on statute.
precedents.cited_holding: The decision must be come to in the spirit and with the sense of responsibility of a tribunal whose duty it is to mete out justice. But it does not follow that the procedure of every such tribunal must be the same.

precedents.citation: General Medical Council v. Spackman 1 ... 1 1943 A.C. 827.

anchor.surface_text: Another recent decision of the House of Lords in the case of General Medical Council v. Spackman 1  was relied upon by the High Court in the judgment under appeal. In that case the General Medical Council, which had been constituted a domestic forum to determine whether a case had been made out for striking off the name of a medical practitioner from the medical register for infamous conduct in a professional respect, was the appellant before their Lordships, and the respondent had been found guilty by the Divorce Court of having committed adultery.

precedents.cited_proposition: Tribunal must conduct due inquiry per statute and rules, including hearing evidence if requested, for striking off professional register.

precedents.citation: R. v. Architects Registration Tribunal 1 ... 1 1945 2 A.E.R. 131.

anchor.surface_text: To that class belongs the case of R. v. Architects Registration Tribunal 1 . In that case the Kings Bench Division issued an order of certiorari to, quash the tribunals decision refusing an application for registration as an architect.

precedents.cited_proposition: Tribunal cannot deprive professional status without opportunity to meet allegations on fitness.

precedents.citation: Leeson v. General Council of Medical Education and Registration 1 ... 1 1890 43 Ch. D. 366.

anchor.surface_text: The cases of Leeson v. General Council of Medical Education and Registration 1 , and Allinson v. General Council of Medical Education and Registration 2  also belong to that category. They deal with the power of the General Council of Medical Education under the Medical Act  21 22 Viet. c. 90  to strike off a medical practitioner for unprofessional conduct.

precedents.case_name: Leeson v. General Council of Medical Education and Registration
precedents.cited_proposition: Medical Council must give full opportunity to person proceeded against in quasi-judicial proceedings for striking off register.

precedents.citation: Allinson v. General Council of Medical Education and Registration 2 ... 2 1894 1 Q.B. 750.

anchor.surface_text: The cases of Leeson v. General Council of Medical Education and Registration 1 , and Allinson v. General Council of Medical Education and Registration 2  also belong to that category. They deal with the power of the General Council of Medical Education under the Medical Act  21 22 Viet. c. 90  to strike off a medical practitioner for unprofessional conduct. Those were cases in which the Medical Council had to function as a quasi-judicial body and had to proceed according to the procedure laid down in the rules framed under the Act aforesaid.

precedents.case_name: Allinson v. General Council of Medical Education and Registration
precedents.cited_proposition: Medical Council must give full opportunity to person proceeded against in quasi-judicial proceedings for striking off register.

precedents.citation: R. v. Archbishop of Canterbury 3 ... 3 1944 1 A.E.R. 179.

anchor.surface_text: Another class of cases is illustrated by the decision of the Court of Appeal in R. v. Archbishop of Canterbury 3 . In that case the Archbishop of Canterbury reviewing the order of the Bishop refused to approve the clerk presented by the patron to a benefice.

precedents.cited_proposition: Not all decisions involving property rights require quasi-judicial procedure; depends on statutory construction.

precedents.citation: Veerappa Pillai v. Raman Raman Ltd. 1 ... 1 1952 S. C. R. 583.

anchor.surface_text: As already pointed out, the Appellate Authority had to function in a quasi-judicial capacity in accordance with the rules made under the Motor Vehicles Act. That Act has made ample provisions for safeguarding the interests of rival claimants for permits. The provisions of the Act were examined in detail by a Bench of five Judges of this Court in the case of Veerappa Pillai v. Raman Raman Ltd. 1 .

precedents.case_name: Veerappa Pillai v. Raman & Raman Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Motor Vehicles Act provides complete scheme for permits with appeals; High Court interference under Art. 226 limited.
precedents.cited_holding: Thus we have before us a complete and precise scheme for regulating the issue of permits, providing what matters are to be taken into consideration as relevant, and prescribing appeals and revisions from subordinate bodies to higher authorities.
